fields.description:
*Assessment*

On a Eucalyptus 4.0.1 cloud, failover traffic for an Eucalyptus ELB configured to do sticky sessions fails to perform like the AWS ELB.  If one of the instances registered to the ELB is terminated, a combination of 503 errors and Connection Refused errors (just like EUCA-9965) is experienced before the traffic is migrated to the running instance.

This behavior seems to be related to EUCA-9919.

*Details*

If a curl test is use to grab the header of the ELB DNS name, when the instance is returned, the following is returned:
{code}
$ while true; do curl -I -k https://SSLDeveloperLB-408396244283.elb.acme.eucalyptus-systems.com; sleep 1; done

{code}

On both Eucalyptus and AWS, the following steps were done:
# Create an ELB with HTTPS/SSL configured
# Create instances with nginx installed
# Make sure port 80 was open, with the following CIDR rule - 0.0.0.0/0
# Register the instances with the ELB
# Create a sticky session policy (in this case, and LB cookie stickiness policy)
# Set the policy to the listener port of the ELB (in this case 443)
# Start the curl test against the DNS name of the ELB
# Terminate one of the instances registered to the ELB
# Monitor the 'curl' test

*Signs*

* full output of 'curl' test on Eucalyptus:
{code}
$ while true; do curl -I -k https://SSLDeveloperLB-408396244283.elb.acme.eucalyptus-systems.com; sleep 1; done

Connection: keep-alive

^C
{code}

*Steps*

# Set up a Eucalyptus 4.0.1 cloud with Eucalytpus DNS, Cloudformation and Load Balancer enabled
# Bundle, upload and register an [Ubuntu Cloud Image (Trusty 14.04)|http://cloud-images.ubuntu.com/trusty/current/trusty-server-cloudimg-amd64-disk1.img] as an instance store-backed HVM EMI
# (Optional) Set up HTTPS/SSL for ELB
** [Uploading SSL Certificates for Elastic Load Balancing|https://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0.1/index.html#user-guide/elb_examples_ssl_certificates.html]
** [Creating a Basic Elastic Load Balancing Configuration|https://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0.1/index.html#user-guide/elb_examples_basic_config.html]
# Create an [Sticky Session policy (for example - Cookie Stickiness Policy)|https://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0.1/index.html#user-guide/elb_examples_sticky_sessions.html] and associate it with the LB port
# Launch 2 instances using the Ubuntu image, and passing the cloud-init.config below to install Nginx:
{code}
$ cat nginx-cloudinit.config
#cloud-config
apt_update: true
apt_upgrade: true
disable_root: true
packages:
 - less
runcmd:
 - [ sh, -xc, "META_HOSTNAME=`curl -s http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/local-hostname`; META_IP=`curl -s http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/local-ipv4`; echo ${META_IP}   ${META_HOSTNAME} >> /etc/hosts" ]
 - [ sh, -xc, "META_HOSTNAME=`curl -s http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/local-hostname`; hostname ${META_HOSTNAME}; sysctl -w kernel.hostname=${META_HOSTNAME}" ]
 - [ apt-get, install, -y, --force-yes, dnsutils ]
 - [ apt-get, install, -y, --force-yes, bind9utils ]
 - [ apt-get, install, -y, --force-yes, mlocate ]
 - [ apt-get, install, -y, --force-yes, nginx ]
{code}
# Make sure port 80 is open in the security group associated with the instances - for 0.0.0.0/0
# register the instances with the ELB
# Run the 'curl' test in another terminal. Use the ELB DNS name in the test.  For example:
{code}
# while true; do curl -I <ELB DNS name>; sleep 1; done
{code}
_NOTE:_ If using HTTPS/SSL ELB, use the -k option with curl
# Terminate one of the registered instances associated with the ELB
# Observe the output of the 'curl' test

*Workaround*

None so far, however, there seems to be a solution based upon a couple of [HAProxy Configuration options|http://cbonte.github.io/haproxy-dconv/configuration-1.5.html].
fields.summary: Eucalyptus ELB with Sticky Sessions Doesn't Match Failover Performance of AWS ELB
fields.environment:
* non-HA, multiple-clusters, DNS, Cloudformation, Load Balancer Enabled
** 1 x CLC, DNS, Cloudformation
** 1 x UFS
** 1 x UFS, Walrus
** 2 x CC (Managed), SC
*** cluster 1 - SC (Overlay)
*** cluster 2 - SC (DAS)
** 2 x NCs per cluster

comments.body:
This is the duplicate of EUCA-9965 (and fixed). 
https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-9965

'curl' can't be used to test session stickiness because each HTTP request is a fresh request (as opposed to request with the cookie)
